description.narrative:
Burkina Faso is experiencing an unprecedented humanitarian crisis that left 1.5m people requiring urgent assistance (HRP, July 2019). Circa 490,000 people have been uprooted from their homes as of 8 October, an increase of 68% since 23 September (OCHA, Oct 2019). Plan's chosen area of intervention - the Centre-Nord - is the region grappling with the largest influx of IDP; as of 8 October, the Bam province hosts 46,872 IDP, the province of Namentenga, 27,195 IDP and the province of Sanmatenga – the most affected, 169,409 IDPs, which represents respectively a 758%, 176% and 88% increase in two weeks (idem).
The precarious security situation in Centre-North is putting additional pressure on the already depleted resources of host communities. It has crippled Education services with 145 primary schools closed, depriving 26,266 children from their right to education (Ministry of Education, Oct 2019). It has exacerbated protection needs and constraints, with 151 cases of human rights violation registered in the Centre-North (67%) and Sahel (33%), including 45 assassinations, 10 cases of physical abuse, 4 of child abuse and 8 of sexual abuse and rape (UNCHR, Sept 2019). The Global Child Protection Area of Responsibility has highlighted abuse, exploitation, child recruitment by armed groups and physically endangerment as additional risks posed to children due to the crisis. As of June 2019, half of the IDP children are estimated to be in need of Psychosocial Support. As of 6 September, out of the 244 cases of UASC identified, 85 (43 girls) had not been reunited with their families (CPiE Sectoral Group, Sept 2019). Other CP issues identified with the potential of being aggravated by the crisis include concerns of child labour, child trafficking, out of school children and early and forced marriage as confirmed in Plan's NA. Thus, Plan will address the urgent needs limiting children and adolescents to enjoy their right to Education and Protection in this complex emergency.

Plan & APJEE's proposed response has the following overall objective: Girls and boys (0-12 years), adolescents (13-17 years) and young women and men (18-24 years) affected by the humanitarian crisis in the Centre-North region of Burkina Faso have access to quality Child and GBV protection services and Education opportunities to prevent and respond to violence, abuse, neglect and exploitation.
Through this action, Plan & APJEE will respond to priority unmet CP and Education needs of internally displaced children, youth and their families in 4 locations with 4 Mobile Child Friendly Spaces (CFS) and 2 Youth Friendly Spaces (YFS) set up as per SPHERE and Cluster standards. The overall approach of the integrated EiE and CPiE response is two-folded and directly responding the the identified Education & Protection needs in the HNO. Plan & APJEE will work to:
1)re-establish community level protective environment comprising psychosocial support, referral to services and capacity strengthening of community members residing in host communities. Empowering CAFAAGs and child GBV survivors (or at risk of) through socio-economic reintegration in an effort to prevent further exploitation and minimize child labor. 2)re-establish access to education for the internally displaced children, in particular for those who are most vulnerable and have not been able to enrol in the formal education system.
This project will complement Save the Children’s CP activities which will be delivered in 2 communes of Centre-North region whilst Plan will deliver in four different communes, ensuring an increased number of conflict-affected children’s needs are met in this JR. Also, Plan seeks improved coordination and synergy with existing active humanitarian actors in the same communes of Centre-Nord (DRC, UNHCR, UNFPA, UNICEF) and state social providers by leading a workshop under this project to ensure referrals to health, nutrition and social services in a timely and adequate manner.

Plan has been active in Burkina Faso since 1976 and well established in the proposed area, including through a Programme Unit in Kaya (Centre-North region). Plan has been responding to the current crisis since 2019 with a portfolio of 3.2M EUR using strong ties in the communities, collaborating with CBOs, government bodies (Ministère de L'Education, Ministère de la Femme, Solidarité nationale, Famille et de l'action humanitarie and Direction Générale de l’Encadrement de la Protection de l’Enfant et de l’Adolescent) and humanitarian actors, and has throughout built expertise in the EiE, CPiE, FSL & NFI sectors to respond to the crisis in Centre-Nord & Sahel.
Plan Burkina Faso is co-lead of the EiE Working Group with UNICEF. Plan provides technical assistance and information management capacity through regular meetings to ensure coordinated, timely and accountable Education response. At national level, Plan is actively involved in other inter-agency coordination efforts to prioritise cross-sector collaboration. Plan is co-lead of the CP Sub-working group with the DGPEA (Direction Générale de l’Encadrement de la Protection de l’Enfant et de l’Adolescent) and UNICEF, lead in the GBV sub-working group with UNFPA and lead in the Cash working group with FAO. Close collaboration will be maintained with UNOCHA and UNDSS for security aspects of the project. Lastly, to ensure access to the most affected areas and enhance a localised response, Plan will work with local partner APJEE.

Plan will be operating out of its Kaya sub-office with local partner-led implementation ensuring accessibility & sustainability of the JR. Plan has been working with AJPEE since the start of the crisis and will continue to build their emergency response capacity. AJPEE has strong expertise and experience in Education and Protection and will be responsible for running the CFS/TLS & YFS, in collaboration with the state social action services. Plan has strong ties with local authorities since before the emergency, and more recently through humanitarian EiE and CPiE projects as well as wide scale NFI distributions. The delivery model is based on service provision and in-kind support, drawing from Plan’s successful experience (PDMs results) since beginning our Centre-Nord response in January 2019. The mobile approach adopted ensures flexibility to respond to the needs of the mobile IDP.

SUMMARY Since early 2019, non-state armed groups have consolidated their presence in especially the northern part of Burkina Faso. There has been a sharp increase in violence with reported civilian deaths four times higher than the total recorded in 2018. The escalating levels of insecurity have led to schools being closed and farmers abandoning their fields in search of safety. In response to the humanitarian situation, Plan International, in collaboration with the Dutch Relief Alliance funded by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, leads the Burkina Faso JR. As of Dec 1 2018, Plan International Netherlands provides multi-sectoral assistance to respond to the immediate needs in protection and education of the most vulnerable and conflict affected people in targeted areas in the region of Centre-Nord for a total duration of 6 months.

The response targets the most vulnerable conflict-affected children, especially unaccompanied and separated children, children associated with armed forces, child GBV survivors and at risk children and adolescents in hard to reach areas such as Bourom and Yalgo. The project will prevent GBV and support GBV survivors, particularly adolescents at risk of GBV. This action owns a strategic advantage due to Plan and APJEE's long lasting presence in Centre-Nord allowing us to access communes and identify beneficiaries based on agreed Cluster selection criteria and in collaboration with local authorities. Plan will be guided by its Child Trafficking Needs Assessment conducted in Kaya. We will target 5,300 beneficiaries, including 2,000 children (0-12 years, 60% girls); 400 adolescents (13-17 years, 50% girls); 200 youth (18-24 years, 60% women) with GBV prevention & response which will be accessible to both IDP (60%) and vulnerable host community (40%) ensuring a conflict-sensitive approach.

sector.narrative: Relief co-ordination; protection and support services

policy-marker.narrative: Protection and Assistance in Emergencies (Disaster Risk Management)

title.narrative: Number of boys and girls that access safe, quality learning opportunities (formal education)

comment.narrative: Number of boys and girls that access safe, quality learning opportunities (formal education)
1000 students affected by the crisis and orphans from CP1 to CM2 have been targeted and provided with school kits consisting of a minimum of 1 schoolbag and books in the 4 localities of the project.
1000 students affected by the crisis and orphans from CP1 to CM2 have been targeted and provided with school kits consisting of a minimum of 1 schoolbag and books in the 4 localities of the project.

title.narrative: Number of boys and girls that access safe, quality learning opportunities (non-formal education)

comment.narrative: Number of boys and girls that access safe, quality learning opportunities (non-formal education)

In view of the situation created by the C-19 pandemic where activities were totally suspended, this activity could not be carried out as initially planned. It has been readapted into recreational activity through the mobile approach in the CFS at the resumption of community activities. Numeracy and literacy sessions were provided to children aged from 6 to 12 years old by recruited CFS animators an teachers.

title.narrative: Number of learning spaces/schools set up or rehabilitated and equipped to meet standards

comment.narrative: Number of learning spaces/schools set up or rehabilitated and equipped to meet standards
6 spaces have been set up including 1 CFS / TLS in KAYA, 1 CFS / TLS in PISSILA, 1 CFS / TLS in KONGOUSSI and 1 CFS / TLS in YALGO. 1 YFS in KAYA and 1 YFS in KONGOUSSI.

title.narrative: Number of teachers and other education personnel trained

comment.narrative: Number of teachers and other education personnel trained

82 school and community members trained - 8 teachers and 16 communty volunteers including 7 men and 17 women have been recruited and trained to facilitate numeracy and literacy classes. 40 Teachers, 08 directors, 07 CCEB, 03 DPPEPNEF, have been trained on the basic principles of child protection, psychosocial support, GBV, safe school and covid-19. Following new strategies developped to cope with covid-19 restrictions the program staff have adopted distance strategy to train and sensitize community members. 800 (400 women and 400 men) including parents, parent-teacher associations, mothers' associations and school management committees were trained and sensitized school safety and reached by back-to-school awareness campaign

82 school and community members trained - 8 teachers and 16 communty volunteers including 7 men and 17 women have been recruited and trained to facilitate numeracy and literacy classes. 40 Teachers, 08 directors, 07 CCEB, 03 DPPEPNEF, have been trained on the basic principles of child protection, psychosocial support, GBV, safe school and covid-19. Following new strategies developped to cope with covid-19 restrictions the program staff have adopted distance strategy to train and sensitize community members. 800 (400 women and 400 men) including parents, parent-teacher associations, mothers' associations and school management committees were trained and sensitized school safety and reached by back-to-school awareness campaign

title.narrative: Number of children that received support specified to their needs

comment.narrative: Number of children that received support specified to their needs

Recreational activities targeted 1,200 children aged 3-17, including 300 children per UTC. Prior to the C-19 pandemic, age-appropriate recreational, child protection, and psychosocial support activities had reached a total of 2,389 children, including 976 boys 0-12 years old, 1,127 girls 0-12 years old, 115 boys 13-17 years old, and 171 girls 13-17 years old. With the new mobile approach adopted, after the lifting of the quarantine, the project teams that reorganized themselves into sub-sites (18) and with a smaller number of children (30) per sub-site to respect the barrier measures were able to reach 3,056 children including 1,644 girls and 1,412 boys aged 0-17 years in the 4 localities. The activities carried out at the different sub-sites focused on psychosocial care activities, including creative, imaginative, physical, communication, manipulative, cultural/traditional, life skills, leisure activities, etc. The activities were carried out in the different sub-sites. These activities included drawings, songs, dances, games, games for women, ludo, soccer cards, as well as sensitization on age-appropriate themes such as malaria, hygiene, diarrheal diseases, C-19, education, GBV, etc.

title.narrative: Number of participants showing an increased knowledge on the protection subject in focus.

description.narrative: Humanitarian support: capacity building in protection

comment.narrative: Number of participants showing an increased knowledge on the protection subject in focus.

171 Parents groups have been established in each area (KAYA-Kongoussi- Yalgo- Pissila), 30 parents were trained per commune. Parents peer educators (community members) who in turn conducted awareness sessions for other members in their the community as per the initial planing. This strategy has been modified in order to respond to Covid-19 restrictions, radio micro programs were developed in collaboration Plan's Communication department and broadcasted in the selected community radio stations. Also 32 animators + 16 volunteers + 3 supervisors were trained to facilitate recreational activities.

This strategy has been modified in order to respond to Covid-19 restrictions, radio micro programs were developed in collaboration Plan's Communication department and broadcasted in the selected community radio stations. title.narrative: Number of persons reached by the implementation of specific GBV prevention measures

comment.narrative: Number of persons reached by the implementation of specific GBV prevention measures

Life skills sessions were conducted and included training in the 4 intervention zones of the project. A total of 360 young people and adolescents saw their skills reinforced on themes adapted to their age, namely, the management of their own emotions and those of others, the tools necessary for daily conflict management, tools necessary to maintain a positive relationship with their peers and with adults in their communities. 90 girls and 90 boys aged 13 to 17 as well as 90 girls and 90 boys aged 18 to 24 were reached by the different sessions in the different localities. Economic empowerment of youth was also an integral part of the project. 100 young people (25/Project intervention zone of which 80% are IDPs and 20% host population) from the four (04) project intervention zones benefited from training in entrepreneurship and business plan development. At the end of this training, all of them were provided with installation kits worth 100,000 francs each. Information sessions on SRHR, GHM, SGBV, CEFM, child trafficking and harmful traditional practices, the importance of education, hygiene and nutrition addressed to children aged 13-17 years old adapted to age and gender and were conducted in CFS and YFS before the pandemic. After the deconfinement, these sessions were readapted and integrated into recreational sessions, mobile awareness sessions (on hygiene, VGB, GHM, etc.) in the sub-sites (mobile approach), and during the training of young people (IGA, making sanitary napkins). The various sessions reached more than 3,000 children and young people in the 4 localities. 240 young people and adolescents (60 per center) were sensitized on the hygienic and daily management of menstruation. They also received training in the manufacturing of reusable sanitary napkins. These 240 young people consisted of 188 IDPs and 52 guests, including 200 girls and 40 boys aged 13 to 24.

title.narrative: Number of persons with increased/appropriate information on relevant rights and/or entitlements

comment.narrative: Number of persons with increased/appropriate information on relevant rights and/or entitlements

8 awareness raising sessions have been realized by established CBCPCs in KAYA. 2800 women and 1121 Men sensitized on children's rights, child protection, hygiene, GBV. The Day of African Child June 16, 2020, has been selected instead of the International Women's day as communities were under lockdown on March 8th due to Covid-19. During the celebration two (2) centers for vulnerable children received support from the project in Kaya and Kongoussi (consisting of food items, non-food items and covid-19 protection materials). With respect to the new sensitizations approaches adopted, 10.000 community members were reached through radio programs, radio micro-programs sensitization and on air games were also realized, a radio panel on protection risks and prevention were also organized with different protection partners and cluster members.

title.narrative: Number of survivors who receive an appropriate response to GBV

comment.narrative: Number of survivors who receive an appropriate response to GBV

Recreational activities for groups of children and youth aged 13-17 years were conducted throughout the implementation of the project. These activities focused on singing, games, games of checkers, games of ludo, cards, soccer, as well as awareness raising on themes adapted to their age. The recreational activities reached more than 150 girls and 150 boys. 240 young people have benefited from capacity building in GHM and 100 in entrepreneurship (life-skill, etc.) in the different areas of intervention of the project. For a better supervision of the children and youths benefiting from the project, periodic meetings of the field teams were organized as well as monthly meetings between the implementing partner and the technical partner, in order to evaluate and redirect the activities so as to reach the set objective. During these meetings, recommendations and suggestions were made for improvements during implementation. In this way, a feedback mechanism has been put in place through four committees (including one per locality) in order to facilitate the feedback of different information to the technical partner (assessments, complaints, etc.).

title.narrative: Gender score of the program design and activities (scale 0-4)

description.narrative: 0=Not measured; 1=Gender unaware; 2=Gender Neutral; 3=Gender Aware; 4=Gender Transformative. For measurement of KPI-6: Percentage of running programme activities that are gender-aware or gender-transformative
